That such an extension of citizenship is implied by the institution of the »new cults of Hellanios and Hellania « and that the distribution of the new land - lots is described by the words co / Sàç co / Sdfavra,  the term Oba being purposely chosen as distinct from Kleros,  may strike some readers as unconvincing.  But that this »complicated and ingenious system« of reforms could not have grown up by accident or by common consent and co - operation among the elements of a discordant state,  and therefore must be the work of a single human lawgiver — and that his name was Lycurgus,  is the author's final and fident assertion. 
8. 
From this survey it will be seen that the author has re - studied the ancient authorities with a diligent and enquiring mind and no lack of rical imagination.  The style is pleasant and free from obscurities and,  in spite of the unusual arrangement of the contents,  the picture of Ancient Sparta as reconstructed here is at first sight intelligible and consistent.  There can be no doubt of her determination to extract all possible material from the sources,  and to leave out of account nothing which might be pertinent to the topic under discussion.  But with this thoroughness,  we must recognise,  goes an equal determination to leave no problem unsolved,  whether or no there is adequate material to provide a satisfactory solution.  We have already had occasion to notice several examples of ingenuity outrunning judgement,  and more will be said later about the handling of epigraphical evidence,  as well as of certain linguistic problems in the Rhetra ; but there is also the larger question,  involved by the whole conception of the book,  namely how far is it permissible to use evidence from the Roman period to fill gaps in our knowledge of ancient Sparta,  and vice - versa. 
We cannot lightly set aside all the evidence for the continuity of tions assembled in chapter I,  but a doubt remains whether under the altered conditions,  both political and social,  which prevailed in Roman Sparta,  such survivals as the Agoge could have been more than shadows of the real thing,  seeing that national service in arms,  the essential purpose of that system,  was now extinct.  The author's explanation,  that it was necessary to maintain the system in order to produce citizens fit to hold civic office is not altogether convincing. 
In spite of the literary evidence for the revival and continuity into Roman times of the Agoge,  it cannot be overlooked that we have no single certain example of the title Kasen either among the dedications of boy victors at the Orthia sanctuary or among the lists of magistrates or other associations during the period of a hundred years or more before A.  D.  50.  Exactly how much truth underlies the account given by Philostratus
